newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-NANTES VISIT SCENE OF REVIVAL.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-NANTES VISIT SCENE OF REVIVAL.

text.p: Nantes take their 21-match unbeaten run to bottom club Nice this weekend hoping for a repeat of the 7-0 victory in September that kick-started their season.
Nantes had not managed a win in their opening 10 games before the floodgates opened againt Nice. They have not lost since, have climbed to sixth place and are challenging for a UEFA Cup place.
In spite of their form, Nantes were not underestimating the Cote d'Azur relegation candidates.

"I don't think the squad have relaxed," said striker Jocelyn Gourvennec. "Even if we have gone through a long series of matches without defeat, no-one's forgetting the nightmare at the start of the season. No-one wants to plunge back into that.

"Our motivation is intact and away from home we are solid, especially at the back, so we're optimistic and we're going to look for a win. But it's not a question of taking victory in Nice for granted."
Nice assistant coach Gaby Desmenez said: "We have to take revenge on Nantes for the humiliation of the 7-0 defeat. We have to erase this dishonour."
Nice have just 19 points and are six adrift of second from bottom Nancy.
Nantes' 3-0 win over third-placed Bastia last weekend was their first home victory since November. But they have won their last four away games.
Gourvennec (10) and Jpahet N'Doram (15) have contributed 25 of the 1995 French champions' 48 goals, a total onlyl matched in the first division by leaders Monaco.
It was a very different picture in September when in 10 games they had picked up only five points, all from draws and only one at home.

Then came the rout of Nice, with seven different scorers, and the unbeaten run which had begun with three successive draws -- their last defeat was at home to Metz in mid-September -- was well under way.
Talisman teenage goalkeeper Mickael Landreau, who has yet to taste defeat in 19 successive first division games, made his debut in the match prior to the Nice victory.

Coach Jean-Claude Suaudeau also warned against complacency when he said the calm that has set in since the win over Bastia "does not mean that we underestimate our opponents. On the contrary, we would surely get punished if we did."
Argentine striker Javier Mazzoni dropped out of the Nantes squad with injury, but defender Eric Decroix returned.
Nice, who have had more than their share of injury problems this season, welcome back Serbian midfielder Zoran Milinkovic.
League leaders Monaco visit Rennes on Thursday to give them more recovery time before next week's UEFA Cup match with Newcastle.
Second-placed Paris St Germain, four points adrift, visit Le Havre while third-placed Bastia host Montpellier.
